<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 194, 220, 208]]<|/det|>
# MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 216, 304, 232]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Mechanics 2 (M2)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 260, 455, 303]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 320, 390, 337]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 351, 828, 367]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 368, 722, 384]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 384, 325, 400]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 400, 495, 416]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 416, 601, 433]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 447, 284, 463]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 463, 907, 494]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 494, 720, 510]]<|/det|>
Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity is needed, use \(10 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 510, 590, 526]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 527, 606, 543]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 557, 606, 573]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 573, 756, 590]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 590, 440, 605]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 606, 907, 636]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) is projected with speed \(15 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\) at an angle of \(60^{\circ}\) above the horizontal. Find the direction of motion of \(P\) at the instant \(0.9 \mathrm{~s}\) after projection. [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 135, 92, 154]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 135, 920, 201]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) of mass \(0.3 \mathrm{~kg}\) is attached to one end of a light elastic string of natural length \(0.6 \mathrm{~m}\) and modulus of elasticity \(45 \mathrm{~N}\). The other end of the string is attached to a fixed point \(O\). The particle \(P\) is released from rest at \(O\) and falls vertically. Find the extension of the string when \(P\) is at its lowest position. [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 230, 92, 248]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 229, 920, 263]]<|/det|>
A ball is projected horizontally with speed \(5 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\) from the top of a tower which is \(30 \mathrm{~m}\) high. The tower stands on horizontal ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 276, 153, 294]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 275, 779, 294]]<|/det|>
Find the speed and direction of motion of the ball when it reaches the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 276, 920, 294]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 307, 153, 325]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 307, 920, 325]]<|/det|>
Calculate the distance from the foot of the tower to the point where the ball reaches the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 323, 920, 341]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 368, 92, 386]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[384, 381, 650, 597]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 617, 920, 682]]<|/det|>
A smooth hollow cylinder of internal radius \(0.3 \mathrm{~m}\) is fixed with its axis vertical. One end of a light inextensible string of length \(0.5 \mathrm{~m}\) is fixed to a point \(A\) on the axis. The other end of the string is attached to a particle \(P\) of mass \(0.2 \mathrm{~kg}\) which moves in a horizontal circle on the surface of the cylinder (see diagram).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 694, 153, 712]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 694, 395, 712]]<|/det|>
Find the tension in the string.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 694, 920, 712]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 725, 153, 744]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 725, 688, 744]]<|/det|>
Find the least angular speed of \(P\) for which the motion is possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 725, 920, 744]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 756, 153, 774]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 756, 920, 791]]<|/det|>
Calculate the magnitude of the force exerted on \(P\) by the cylinder given that the speed of \(P\) is \(1.8 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 772, 920, 791]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
One end of a light elastic string \(S_{1}\) of modulus of elasticity \(20 \mathrm{~N}\) and natural length \(0.5 \mathrm{~m}\) is attached to a fixed point \(O\). The other end of \(S_{1}\) is attached to a particle \(P\) of mass \(0.4 \mathrm{~kg}\). \(P\) hangs in equilibrium vertically below \(O\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 135, 336, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[136, 135, 336, 153]]<|/det|>
Find the distance \(OP\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 166, 920, 216]]<|/det|>
The opposite ends of a light inextensible string \(S_{2}\) of length \(l \text{m}\) are now attached to \(O\) and \(P\) respectively. The elastic string \(S_{1}\) remains attached to \(O\) and \(P\). The particle \(P\) hangs in equilibrium vertically below \(O\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 229, 154, 247]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 227, 767, 247]]<|/det|>
Find the tension in the inextensible string \(S_{2}\) for each of the following cases:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 254, 180, 272]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 254, 260, 272]]<|/det|>
\(l < 0.5\);

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 280, 180, 297]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 280, 260, 297]]<|/det|>
\(l > 0.6\);

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 305, 180, 323]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 305, 268, 323]]<|/det|>
\(l = 0.54\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 320, 920, 338]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 348, 897, 368]]<|/det|>
In the case \(l = 0.54\), the inextensible string \(S_{2}\) suddenly breaks and \(P\) begins to descend vertically.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 380, 151, 397]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 380, 631, 397]]<|/det|>
Calculate the greatest speed of \(P\) in the subsequent motion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 380, 920, 397]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 426, 92, 444]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[306, 435, 727, 603]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 622, 920, 687]]<|/det|>
A uniform solid cone of height \(1.2 \mathrm{~m}\) and semi-vertical angle \(\theta^{\circ}\) is divided into two parts by a cut parallel to and \(0.4 \mathrm{~m}\) from the circular base. The upper conical part, \(C\), has weight \(16 \mathrm{~N}\), and the lower part, \(L\), has weight \(38 \mathrm{~N}\). The two parts of the solid rest in equilibrium with the larger plane face of \(L\) on a horizontal surface and the smaller plane face of \(L\) covered by the base of \(C\) (see diagram).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 700, 153, 718]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 700, 754, 718]]<|/det|>
Calculate the distance of the centre of mass of \(L\) from its larger plane face.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 700, 920, 718]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 730, 920, 764]]<|/det|>
An increasing horizontal force is applied to the vertex of \(C\). Equilibrium is broken when the magnitude of this force first exceeds \(4 \mathrm{~N}\), and \(C\) begins to slide on \(L\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 778, 153, 796]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 778, 415, 796]]<|/det|>
By considering the forces on \(C\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 803, 180, 821]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 803, 581, 821]]<|/det|>
find the coefficient of friction between \(C\) and \(L\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 803, 920, 821]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 828, 190, 845]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 828, 601, 845]]<|/det|>
show that \(\theta > 14.0\), correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 828, 920, 845]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 858, 744, 876]]<|/det|>
\(C\) is removed and \(L\) is placed with its curved surface on the horizontal surface.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 890, 151, 907]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 890, 571, 907]]<|/det|>
Given that \(L\) is on the point of toppling, calculate \(\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 890, 920, 907]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
A small ball \(B\) of mass \(0.2 \mathrm{kg}\) moves in a narrow fixed smooth cylindrical tube \(OA\) of length \(1 \mathrm{m}\), closed at the end \(A\). When the ball has displacement \(x \mathrm{m}\) from \(O\), it has velocity \(v \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) in the direction \(OA\) and experiences a resisting force of magnitude \(\frac{k}{1 - x} \mathrm{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 149, 153, 166]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[339, 163, 734, 230]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 252, 920, 303]]<|/det|>
The tube is fixed in a horizontal position and \(B\) is projected from \(O\) towards \(A\) with velocity \(1.2 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) (see diagram). Given that \(B\) comes to instantaneous rest after travelling \(0.55 \mathrm{m}\), show that \(k = 0.1803\), correct to 4 significant figures. [6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 316, 151, 333]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 316, 920, 349]]<|/det|>
The tube is now fixed in a vertical position with \(O\) above \(A\). The ball \(B\) is released from rest at \(O\). Calculate the speed of \(B\) after it has descended \(0.1 \mathrm{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 331, 920, 348]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]
